Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effects of Intravenous Anesthetics on Ischemia-Reperfusion Injury

Background: This study evaluates the protective effects of intravenous anesthetics on ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI) in both animal and clinical settings, focusing on dosage and molecular effects.

Methods: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with individual participants as the unit of randomisation. The sample size was determined based on anticipated effect sizes from prior research. Participants were eligible if they were undergoing surgical procedures with potential IRI, and the study was completed in a hospital setting. The intervention involved administering intravenous anesthetics, while the control group received standard care. Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed with sealed envelopes. Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Results: The primary outcome was the reduction in tissue injury, assessed over a 24-hour period post-intervention. A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, recruited between January 2020 and June 2021. Analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach. The intervention group demonstrated a significant reduction in tissue injury (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01). Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing side effects.

Harm: Adverse events were mild and occurred in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.
